title: Magic pull away, beat Celtics despite another big Jaylen Brown game: 8 takeaways
author: Tom Westerholm
bullets: The Boston Celtics lost 123-110 to the Orlando Magic in the NBA Cup, despite Jaylen Brown's 32-point performance.
Celtics' defense faltered, conceding 38 points in the first and fourth quarters; Magic hit 17 three-pointers.
Payton Pritchard improved his 3-point shooting, scoring 27 points on 5-for-8 from beyond the arc against the Magic.

title: Public reprimand recommended for judge accused of helping immigrant escape ICE
author: Morgan Rousseau
bullets: Judge Shelley Joseph recommended for public reprimand after creating 'appearance of impropriety' in 2018 ICE evasion case.
Hearing officer Denis J. McInerney found Judge Joseph did not know about nor authorize the escape plan.
Federal charges against Judge Joseph dropped in 2022; she was initially charged with obstruction of justice in 2019.

title: Alex Cora still high on Red Sox’ future a month after being eliminated by Yankees
author: Kaley Brown
bullets: Red Sox manager Alex Cora remains optimistic about team's future despite playoff elimination by Yankees.
Boston Red Sox face offseason uncertainty with player contract decisions and potential trades looming.
Cora expects improved performance in 2026 with contributions from emerging players like Roman Anthony.

title: Giant blade breaks off Mass. wind turbine
author: Morgan Rousseau
bullets: A wind turbine blade detached and landed in a cranberry bog on Head of the Bay Road, Plymouth.
The turbine, about 300 feet tall, went into 'fail-safe mode' and shut down automatically after the blade detached.
No injuries were reported, and officials stated there was no public danger; the site was assessed and secured.

title: 5 must-watch movies & TV shows streaming right now
author: Kevin Slane
bullets: 'The Fantastic Four: First Steps' streams on Disney+, starting Phase 6 of the MCU with a competent adaptation.
'Frankenstein' by Guillermo del Toro, with Oscar Isaac and Jacob Elordi, is streaming on Netflix.
'Death by Lightning', a Netflix series about President James A. Garfield's assassination, features Michael Shannon and Matthew Macfadyen.

title: Stefon Diggs reveals what he’s trying to improve about himself after 11 years in the NFL
author: Kaley Brown
bullets: Stefon Diggs leads Patriots receivers with 508 yards, 56.4 yards per game, and 45 receptions this season.
Diggs focuses on improving his attitude, seeking balance between competitiveness and self-perfection.
Veteran leadership and coaching praised for fostering success for Patriots' offensive players this season.

title: Commuter train plows through car on tracks in Acton
author: Morgan Rousseau
bullets: An MBTA commuter train hit an empty car at a Central Street crossing in Acton, pushing it 300 feet.
The car drove around closed gates; no injuries reported. The driver will be cited, police stated.
The crash caused delays on the Fitchburg line; commuters were advised to use alternative train services.

title: What to know about possible Red Sox free agent target Munetaka Murakami after posting
author: Conor Roche
bullets: Japanese star Munetaka Murakami, known as the 'Japanese Babe Ruth,' has been posted by the Tokyo Yakult Swallows.
Murakami, 25, hit 142 home runs in Nippon Professional Baseball from 2022-2025, leading several offensive categories.
MLB teams, including the Red Sox, Dodgers, and Mariners, are potential suitors for Murakami before the December 22 signing deadline.

title: Airlines are waiving fees, offering refunds due to reduced flight schedules
author: Kristi Palma
bullets: The FAA reduced flights by 10% at 40 airports, including Logan, due to a government shutdown.
JetBlue waives change fees and refunds passengers for flights canceled between Nov. 6-10, rebooking through Nov. 19.
American Airlines offers refunds and waives change fees for tickets bought by Nov. 5, for travel Nov. 7-14.

title: After Cape Cod crash, readers say Mass. should tighten e-bike regulations
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: A crash on Cape Cod sparked debate on Massachusetts e-bike regulations after a 69-year-old was injured on the Rail Trail.
78% of over 580 readers support stricter e-bike rules, citing safety concerns due to their growing usage on trails.
Massachusetts currently treats Class 1 and 2 e-bikes like regular bikes; Class 3 bikes, capable of 20+ mph, lack regulation.
